content.question: Which statement is true about the approaches used to measure the value of a nationâ€™s gross domestic product <math alttext="open parenthesis, G D P, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>GDP</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: The expenditures approach to calculating <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></math> sums the components of the supply side of the economy.
The income approach to calculating <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></math> sums the income earned by the factors of production excluding profits.

The value-added approach to calculating <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sums the final monetary value of output at each stage of production.

The expenditures approach to calculating <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sums the market value of all final goods and services produced by foreigners in a given period of time.

The expenditures approach to calculating <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sums consumption spending, investment spending, government spending, and net exports.

content.answer: The expenditures approach to calculating <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sums consumption spending, investment spending, government spending, and net exports.
